content.title: Ventilator Weaning and Liberation
content.summary: Ventilator weaning is the systematic process of discontinuing mechanical ventilation while monitoring for tolerance. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) with protocolized assessment have been shown to reduce ventilator days. Success depends on resolution of the underlying disease, adequate respiratory mechanics, and absence of new complications.
key_points: Daily screening for readiness: resolving disease, adequate oxygenation (P/F ≥150), hemodynamically stable, awake
Spontaneous breathing trial (SBT): 30-120 min on minimal support (PSV 5-8 or T-piece) assessing tolerance
SBT failure signs: RR >35, SpO2 <90%, HR >140 or change >20%, SBP >180 or <90, agitation/distress
Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI): RR/VT in L; >105 predicts failure; <105 suggests success (PPV ~80%)
Sedation vacation (awakening trial) paired with SBT improves outcomes (ABC bundle)
Post-extubation stridor risk: cuff leak test; dexamethasone prophylaxis if at risk
content.statement: Liberation from mechanical ventilation should be considered daily once the underlying indication resolves. Protocolized spontaneous breathing trials with integrated awakening trials reduce duration of mechanical ventilation and ICU length of stay.

explanation.intuition: Prolonged mechanical ventilation leads to diaphragm atrophy (ventilator-induced diaphragmatic dysfunction), increased infection risk, and ICU-acquired weakness. Early and frequent assessment of readiness for liberation improves outcomes. The SBT tests the patient's ability to sustain adequate gas exchange and work of breathing independently.
explanation.key_insight: The rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI = RR/VT in liters) is the most validated weaning predictor, but no single parameter is sufficient. Integrating daily awakening trials with breathing trials (ABCs) reduces ventilator days by identifying patients ready for liberation who might otherwise remain oversedated.
explanation.technical_details: SBT options: T-piece (no ventilator support), CPAP 5, or PSV 5-8/PEEP 5. Duration 30-120 minutes. Extubation criteria: passed SBT, adequate cough (white card test), manageable secretions, patent upper airway. Cuff leak test: deflate cuff and occlude ETT - audible air leak suggests adequate laryngeal patency.

definitions_glossary.ventilator_weaning: Systematic reduction in ventilator support and assessment of readiness for liberation from mechanical ventilation
definitions_glossary.spontaneous_breathing_trial: SBT: period of minimal or no ventilator support (30-120 min) to assess ability to breathe independently
definitions_glossary.rapid_shallow_breathing_index: RSBI = respiratory rate / tidal volume (in liters); >105 predicts failure, <105 predicts success
definitions_glossary.t_piece_trial: SBT with complete removal from ventilator; patient breathes through T-piece with humidified oxygen
definitions_glossary.pressure_support_trial: SBT with minimal PSV (5-8 cmH2O) and low PEEP (5 cmH2O)
definitions_glossary.awakening_trial: Daily interruption of sedation to assess mental status and readiness for liberation
definitions_glossary.abc_bundle: Awakening and Breathing Coordination: paired SAT (spontaneous awakening) + SBT
definitions_glossary.extubation_failure: Reintubation within 48-72 hours of planned extubation; associated with increased mortality
definitions_glossary.cuff_leak_test: Assessment for post-extubation stridor by measuring air leak around deflated ETT cuff
definitions_glossary.ventilator_induced_diaphragm_dysfunction: Diaphragm atrophy and weakness from prolonged controlled ventilation
definitions_glossary.weaning_predictor: Physiologic parameter used to predict SBT/extubation success (RSBI, NIF, vital capacity)
definitions_glossary.tracheostomy: Surgical airway for patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation; typically after 10-14 days

pathophysiology.mechanism: Successful weaning requires: (1) Adequate respiratory drive (intact CNS, no oversedation), (2) Respiratory muscle strength (no critical illness myopathy, adequate nutrition), (3) Manageable respiratory load (resolved lung disease, no excessive secretions), (4) Cardiovascular reserve (no cardiac decompensation with increased work of breathing), (5) Psychological readiness (not agitated or delirious).
key_pathways: Controlled ventilation → diaphragm disuse → atrophy (VIDD) within 18-48 hours
Prolonged intubation → laryngeal edema → post-extubation stridor risk
Sedation → delayed awakening → prolonged ventilator time
Heart failure → increased work of breathing → LV afterload → weaning failure
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Each additional day of mechanical ventilation increases mortality, VAP risk, and healthcare costs. Protocolized daily assessment reduces unnecessary ventilator days.

readiness_screening.prerequisite: Underlying cause of respiratory failure resolving or resolved
readiness_screening.oxygenation: P/F ratio ≥150 (or SpO2 ≥90% on FiO2 ≤0.40 and PEEP ≤8)
readiness_screening.hemodynamics: No vasopressors or low-dose only; no active ischemia
readiness_screening.neurologic: Awake, following commands, or at baseline mental status; no sedation infusions
readiness_screening.other: No planned procedures requiring sedation; afebrile; adequate hemoglobin

weaning_predictors.negative_inspiratory_force: NIF <-20 to -30 cmH2O suggests adequate respiratory muscle strength

sbt_protocol.duration: 30-120 minutes; 30 min may be sufficient for many patients
sbt_protocol.monitoring: Continuous SpO2, HR, BP, RR; observe for distress signs

extubation_readiness: Cuff leak if at risk for stridor
post_extubation: High-flow nasal cannula or NIV for high-risk patients

if_sbt_failed.immediate: Resume pre-SBT ventilator settings; rest 24 hours
if_sbt_failed.evaluation: Identify and treat reversible causes (fluid overload, infection, cardiac ischemia, delirium)

prolonged_ventilation.tracheostomy: Consider after 10-14 days if ongoing ventilator need expected
prolonged_ventilation.gradual_weaning: Progressive reduction in PSV, SIMV rate, or gradual SBT lengthening
prolonged_ventilation.specialized_weaning_unit: Long-term acute care (LTAC) for patients requiring extended weaning

skos.definition: The systematic process of discontinuing mechanical ventilation support through assessment of readiness, spontaneous breathing trials, and careful extubation decision-making

learning_objectives: Apply daily readiness screening criteria for ventilator liberation
Perform and interpret spontaneous breathing trial results
Calculate and apply the rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) in weaning decisions
Recognize signs of SBT failure and appropriate interventions
Integrate awakening and breathing trials (ABC bundle) in ICU care
clinical_pearls: RSBI <105 predicts success but has only ~80% PPV - clinical judgment still essential
Pair daily awakening trial with SBT (ABC bundle) - reduces vent days significantly
PSV 5-8 / PEEP 5 trial is equivalent to T-piece for most patients and better tolerated
Failed SBT = 24-hour rest then retry; identify and treat reversible causes
Cardiac patients may fail weaning due to increased afterload during spontaneous breathing
Cuff leak test: leak <110 mL or <24% suggests stridor risk; give dexamethasone pre-extubation
common_misconceptions: Weaning should be gradual for all patients (most can be liberated after single successful SBT)
Higher RSBI always means failure (it's a predictor, not absolute; clinical assessment matters)
Only respiratory therapists perform SBT (nurse-driven protocols are effective and standard)

citations.title: Efficacy and safety of a paired sedation and ventilator weaning protocol for mechanically ventilated patients in intensive care

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on major trials (ABC trial) and ATS/CHEST guidelines
